Distributed Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Gradient Quantization for Federated Learning Enabled Vehicle Edge Computing

Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) can protect the privacy of the vehicles in vehicle edge computing (VEC) to a certain extent through sharing the gradients of vehicles’ local models instead of local data. The gradients of vehicles’ local models are usually large for the vehicular artificial intelligence (AI) applications, thus transmitting such large gradients would cause large per-round latency. Gradient quantization has been proposed as one effective approach to reduce the per-round latency in FL enabled VEC through compressing gradients and reducing the number of bits, i.e., the quantization level, to transmit gradients. The selection of quantization level and thresholds determines the quantization error, which further affects the model accuracy and training time. To do so, the total training time and quantization error (QE) become two key metrics for the FL enabled VEC. It is critical to jointly optimize the total training time and QE for the FL enabled VEC. However, the time-varying channel condition causes more challenges to solve this problem. In this paper, we propose a distributed deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based quantization level allocation scheme to optimize the long-term reward in terms of the total training time and QE. Extensive simulations identify the optimal weighted factors between the total training time and QE, and demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed scheme.

Index Terms:
vehicle edge computing, federated learning, gradient quantization, distributed deep reinforcement learning.

I Introduction

With the rapid development of autonomous driving technology, a large amount of data are generated by various sensors on vehicles, such as cameras, radar, lidar, as well as proximity and temperature sensors[1]. For example, a self-driving car is expected to generate about 1 GB of data per second[2]. Vehicles need powerful computing capability to process and analyze the data to support the modeling training of the vehicular artificial intelligence (AI) applications such as simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM), augmented reality (AR) navigation, object tracking, and high-definition (HD) map generation[3]. However, the computing capability of vehicles is limited. In this situation, vehicle edge computing (VEC) becomes a promising technology to facilitate these applications, where a base station (BS) connected with an edge server can collect and utilize the vehicles’ data for model training[4, 5, 6]. However, the raw data generated by a vehicle often contains personal information, thus there may be a risk of data leakage in data privacy in VEC[7].

Recently, federated learning (FL) has been enabled in VEC[8]. FL can protect the privacy of vehicles to a certain extent through sharing the gradients of vehicles’ local models instead of local data[9]. FL training process consists of multiple rounds. For each round, vehicles individually train their local models using local data, then the BS collects the gradients of local models and aggregates them to obtain a global model, after that the edge server sends the global model to vehicles for the next round training. After meeting the convergence requirement, i.e., reaching the desired precision or the predefined loss value, the entire training process is completed[10]. The gradients of vehicles’ local models are usually large for the vehicular AI applications, thus transmitting such large gradients would cause large per-round latency[11, 12].

Gradient quantization may reduce the per-round latency in FL enabled VEC through compressing gradients and reducing the number of bits, i.e., the quantization level, to transmit gradients. In gradient quantization, how to determine the quantization level is a key issue[13]. On one hand, a few quantization level may significantly reduce the transmission overhead, thus cause a low per-round latency and further result in a small total training time. On the other hand, lower number of quantization levels may produce bigger quantization error (QE) due to the heavily compression, which may increase the number of rounds required for convergence and increase the total training time[14, 15]. That means there exists a reasonable gradient quantization level which can adjust the trade off between the total training time and QE for the FL enabled VEC. If only the total training time is optimized, it may lead to the excessive pursuit of large quantization error and the sacrifice of model performance in order to reduce the number of communication rounds, and it is difficult to guarantee the convergence quality and accuracy of the model[16]. Therefore, it is critical to jointly optimize the total training time and QE for the FL enabled VEC. To best of our knowledge, there is no work presented, which motivates us to conduct this work.

In the FL enabled VEC, the channel condition is time-varying due to the time-varying path loss caused by the mobility of the vehicle, which causes challenges to conduct this work[17, 18]. Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) is a favorable framework to solve such problem in complex environments[19]. There are existing papers adopting the centralized DRL framework to dynamically adjust the quantization level in wireless networks[20, 21]. However, the centralized DRL framework lead to significantly high traffic load. In addition, for the centralized DRL framework, the high mobility of vehicles makes the BS difficult to collect accurate instantaneous channel state information (CSI)[22]. On the contrary, in the distributed DRL framework, each vehicle makes decisions independently and does not need to send all the information to the central node, which can reduce the communication overhead and can reduce the network traffic blocking to the BS at the same time[23]. Since each vehicle makes decisions based on its own state, distributed DRL can better collect the CSI[24, 25]. Based on the above analysis, it is necessary to find a proper distributed DRL framework to allocate the quantization levels in the FL enabled VEC.

In this paper, we consider the time-varying channel conditions and propose a distributed DRL-based quantization level allocation scheme by optimizing the long-term reward in terms of the total training time and QE111The source code has been released at: https://github.com/qiongwu86/Distributed Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Gradient Quantization for Federated Learning Enabled Vehicle Edge Computing. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

  • 1)

    For each round, if a vehicle is moving at the edge of the BS’s coverage, it may have no enough time to participate in the current round of the FL. Hence, the global model may be inaccurate if the vehicle is selected to participate in training of the round. Moreover, the certain vehicles with the similar local model may not need to upload frequently. To avoid such phenomenon, we propose a mobility and model-aware vehicle selection rule to select the vehicles to participate in the training of each round.

  • 2)

    We take the computation time and uploading time in each FL as well as the time-varying channel condition into account and formulate an optimization problem which jointly optimizes the training time and quantization error through allocating quantization level.

  • 3)

    We construct the distributed DRL framework including state, action and reward, and adopt the double deep Q-network (DDQN) algorithm to solve the formulated optimization problem, thus the adaptive quantization level allocation can be obtained in a completely distributed way.

  • 4)

    Extensive simulation experiments are carried to demonstrated the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed quantization level allocation scheme.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II reviews the related works. Section III introduces the system model. Section IV and Section V formulate the VEC problem in FL and the optimization problem for quantization level allocation problem, respectively. Section VI presents a solution to the optimized problem based on the distributed DRL. Various simulation results and some discussions are presented in Section VII. Finally, Section VIII concludes this paper.

II Related Work

In this section, we review the existing works on the optimizations of the training time for FL, the works on the optimizations of the QE for FL, as well as the works on the DRL based performance optimization for FL.

II-A Optimizations of the training time for FL

In [26], Liu et al. jointly considered data and model and proposed a method to fit the total communication rounds and minimize the total training time of FL through optimizing quantization and bandwidth. In [27], Yang et al. proposed a bandwidth allocation optimization method to minimize the total training time of FL based on the relationship between communication rounds and learning accuracy. In [28], Wang et al. proposed a quantization and bandwidth allocation method to minimize the training time of FL based on the sample of the presence of the outage probability. In [29], Wan et al. minimized the total training time of FL in wireless networks through adaptive resource scheduling. In [30], Chen et al. minimized the total training time of FL by combining the optimization of user selection and resource block (RB) allocation. In [31], Jiang et al. proposed a novel FL method to adapt to the model size, reducing communication and computation overhead, minimizing the overall training time while maintaining a similar accuracy to the original model. In [32], Nguyen et al. proposed an efficient FL algorithm to allow a small number of clients to participate in the training process based on the unbiased sampling strategy in each round, and then adopted the proposed FL algorithm to formulate the wireless internet of things (IoT) resource allocation problem to minimize the training time. However, these works have not optimized the quantization error of FL.

II-B Optimizations of the quantization error for FL

In [33], Wang et al. minimized quantization error of FL through jointly allocating wireless bandwidth and quantization level. In [34], Hönig et al. minimized the communication cost under the constraint of quantization error and kept the quantization error of FL at the static quantization level by assigning different quantization levels to the client. In [35], Jhunjhunwala et al. proposed an adaptive quantization strategy to achieve a low quantization error upper bound of FL by changing the quantization level during training. In [36, 37], Shlezinger et al. proposed a general vector quantization scheme based on dithered lattice quantization to reduce the quantization error of FL. In [38], Chen et al. proposed the federated learning with heterogeneous quantization (FEDHQ) by assigning aggregate weights to minimize an upper bound on the convergence rate, which is a function of quantization error. In [39], Nori et al. minimized the quantization error of FL for a given wall-clock time by dynamically adjusting the local update coefficients. However, these works have not considered optimizing the training time of FL.

II-C DRL based optimizations for FL

In [40], Wang et al. proposed a method based on the multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradient (MADDPG) to realize fully distributed self-allocation of multi-dimensional resources and optimize the cost of participants in FL. In [41], Zhang et al. proposed an FL algorithm assisted by DRL, which can balance the privacy and efficiency of data training for the industrial internet of things (IIoT) devices. In [42], Do et al. proposed a DRL-based framework for joint UAV placement and resource allocation to enable the sustainable FL with energy harvesting user devices. In [43], Wu et al. proposed a DRL-based optimization and clustering approach for computation constrained devices to accelerate local training of FL by offloading deep neural networks (DNNs) to the server. However, these works have not considered jointly optimizing the training time and quantization error of FL.

As mentioned above, there is no work jointly optimizing the training time and quantization error of FL in VEC based on DRL, which is the motivation of our work in this paper.

III System Model

We consider a quantized FL system consisting of N𝑁N vehicles and a BS connected with an edge server. The vehicles are driving in the coverage of the BS. The velocities of different vehicles follow Gaussian distribution and the velocity of each vehicle is not changed. The driving duration of the vehicles is divided into time slots[44]. The set of the vehicles is denoted by 𝒱={V1,V2,V3,⋯,Vn,⋯,VN}𝒱subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2subscript𝑉3⋯subscript𝑉𝑛⋯subscript𝑉𝑁\mathcal{V}=\{V_{1},V_{2},V_{3},\vbox{\hbox{$\cdots$}},V_{n},\vbox{\hbox{$\cdots$}},V_{N}\}. Each vehicle Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} is equipped with a MEC processor that provides the local processing capability. Vehicles get the data samples through sensors or communication, and each vehicle Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} holds the local dataset 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} with a uniform size of D𝐷D, the dataset 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} contains data samples {(𝐱i,yi)}i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝐷\left\{(\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i})\right\}_{i=1}^{D}, where 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} represents the feature of the data sample and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} represents the label of the data sample[45]. The features of the data sample are used as the input of the model training, and the labels of the data sample are the expected outputs corresponding to the input data, which are used to train and validate the model[46, 47, 48].

Vehicles adopt the quantized FL to obtain the global model through training in rounds. The BS first selects vehicles based on the mobility and model-aware vehicle selection algorithm to participate in training at the beginning of each round r𝑟r. Assume that the set of selected vehicles in each round r𝑟r is denoted by 𝒦r={V1,V2,V3,⋯,Vk,⋯,VK}superscript𝒦𝑟subscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2subscript𝑉3⋯subscript𝑉𝑘⋯subscript𝑉𝐾\mathcal{K}^{r}=\{V_{1},V_{2},V_{3},\vbox{\hbox{$\cdots$}},V_{k},\vbox{\hbox{$\cdots$}},V_{K}\}, where K𝐾K is the number of the selected vehicles in each round r𝑟r (K𝐾K ≤\leq N𝑁N). Then each selected vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} downloads the current global model 𝐰gr∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} from the BS, where d𝑑d denotes the model size, then each vehicle randomly selects samples from the dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} in a uniform manner to obtain a mini-batch and computes the local stochastic gradient 𝐠krsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r} based on the mini-batch. Next, each selected vehicle makes a decision based on its local observation to determine the quantization level which can optimize the training time and quantization error, then adopts the widely-used stochastic gradient quantization to quantize the local gradient and obtain the quantized gradient 𝒬​(𝐠kr)𝒬superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r})[15]. Then, all selected vehicles upload their quantized gradients to the BS, where the orthogonal frequency division multiple access (OFDMA) technology[49, 50] is adopted for the communication between each vehicle and the BS. Afterwards, the BS aggregates the quantized gradients of all vehicles to obtain the updated global model 𝐰gr+1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟1\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r+1} which is used for the training of the next round. The round is repeated until the global model is convergent. The network model is shown in Fig. 1. For ease of understanding, the key notations have been summarized in TABLE I.

IV Quantized Federated Learning Algorithm for Vehicle Edge Computing

In this section, we introduce the quantized FL algorithm for VEC. The pseudocode of the algorithm is shown in Algorithm 1.

First, the BS initializes the global model for round 00, which is denoted by 𝐰g0superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔0\mathbf{w}_{g}^{0}. Then the training is conducted for R+1𝑅1R+1 rounds. For each round r𝑟r, each vehicle Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} first downloads the global model 𝐰grsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r} from the BS (lines 1-3). Then, the mobility and model-aware vehicle selection algorithm is conducted to select the vehicles which have enough time to participate in this round and do not have similar models.

Specifically, a planar rectangular coordinate system is established with the BS as the center and each vehicle Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} first obtains its own mobility information, i.e., the current X-axis coordinate of Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n}, denoted by xnrsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑟x_{n}^{r}, and the velocity of Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n}, denoted by vnrsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛𝑟v_{n}^{r}. Then, the BS calculates the average time of a round, denoted by Tgrsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑔𝑟T_{g}^{r}, which is calculated by averaging the durations of the rounds before round r𝑟r and sends Tgrsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑔𝑟T_{g}^{r} as well as the decision threshold φ∗superscript𝜑∗\varphi^{\ast} to each vehicle. After that each vehicle Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} loads its local model 𝐰nrsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑛𝑟\mathbf{w}_{n}^{r} (lines 4-7).

Assuming that the radius of the BS is RBsubscript𝑅𝐵R_{B}, each vehicle Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} calculates its residence time within the coverage of the BS as (line 8)

Each vehicle Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} calculates the utility φnrsuperscriptsubscript𝜑𝑛𝑟\varphi_{n}^{r} to determine if vehicle Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} is selected to participate in round r𝑟r. Vehicles with similar local models to the global model contribute less to the training of the current global model and do not need to participate in the training frequently. Meanwhile, the selected vehicles need to have enough time to participate in the current round of training and upload the local model[51]. where the quantization function 𝒬​(gkr,j)𝒬superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑟𝑗{\cal Q}\left({{g_{k}^{r,j}}}\right) consists of three parts, i.e., the vector norm ‖𝐠kr‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}\|, the sign of each element sgn​(gkr,j)sgnsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑟𝑗\mathrm{sgn}(g_{k}^{r,j}) , and the normalized quantization value of each element ξj​(𝐠kr,qkr)subscript𝜉𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟\xi_{j}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r},q_{k}^{r}), which is a random variable defined as

ξj​(𝐠kr,qkr)={(l+1)/qkr,w.p.​|gkr,j|‖𝐠kr‖​qkr−l,l/qkr,otherwise.subscript𝜉𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟cases𝑙1superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟w.p.superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑟𝑗normsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟𝑙missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟otherwise.missing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpression{\xi_{j}}\left(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r},q_{k}^{r}\right)=\left\{{\begin{array}[]{*{20}{c}}(l+1)/q_{k}^{r},&{\text{w.p.}\;\frac{{\left|{{g_{k}^{r,j}}}\right|}}{{\left\|{\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}}\right\|}}q_{k}^{r}-l},\\ l/q_{k}^{r},&{{\text{otherwise.}}}\end{array}}\right. (9)

Here, 0≤l<qkr0𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟0\leq l<q_{k}^{r} is an integer such that gkr,j‖𝐠kr‖∈[lqkr,l+1qkr)superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑟𝑗normsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟𝑙1superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟\frac{g_{k}^{r,j}}{\left\|{\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}}\right\|}\in\left[\frac{l}{q_{k}^{r}},\frac{l+1}{q_{k}^{r}}\right).

Next, each selected vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} transmits the quantized local gradient , i.e., 𝒬​(𝐠kr)𝒬superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}), and its local loss function F​(𝐰kr)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}) to the BS. After the BS receives the quantized local gradients and local loss functions from all vehicles, the BS aggregates the quantized local gradients and updates the global model as (lines 18-19)

𝐰gr+1=𝐰gr−ηrK​∑k=1K𝒬​(𝐠kr).superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟subscript𝜂𝑟𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑘1𝒬superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r+1}=\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r}-\frac{\eta_{r}}{K}\sum^{K}_{k=1}\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}). (10)

Then the BS calculates the global loss function as (line 20)

F​(𝐰gr)=1K​∑k=1KF​(𝐰kr).𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝐾𝑘1𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r})=\frac{1}{K}\sum^{K}_{k=1}F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}). (11)

Then the global model that minimizes the global loss function from the first round to the current round r𝑟r is calculated as,

𝐰∗r=arg​min𝐰grF​(𝐰gr).superscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑟subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{r}=\arg\mathop{\min}_{\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r}}F(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r}). (12)

Next the BS calculates the difference between the global loss of the current round, i.e., F​(𝐰gr)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r}), and the global loss of the optimal global model, i.e., F​(𝐰∗r)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{r}). If λ𝜆\lambda-optimal difference is satisfied, i.e.,

F​(𝐰gr)−F​(𝐰∗r)≤λ,𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑟𝜆F(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r})-F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{r})\leq\lambda, (13)

the global model is converged, where λ𝜆\lambda is the loss optimality difference. In this case, the training process stops and the algorithm outputs the global model 𝐰grsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔𝑟\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r} as the optimal global model 𝐰∗subscript𝐰∗\mathbf{w}_{\ast} (lines 21-22). Otherwise, all vehicles download the updated global model from the BS to start the next round. When the number of rounds reaches R𝑅R, the training process stops and the algorithm outputs the global model 𝐰∗Rsuperscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑅\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{R} as the optimal global model 𝐰∗subscript𝐰∗\mathbf{w}_{\ast}.

V Problem Formulation

In this section, we formulate the problem to jointly optimize the training time and QE. We first formulate the training time and QE, respectively. Then we formulate the optimization problem.

V-A Training time

The FL delay of round r𝑟r for vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k}, denoted by Tkr,fedsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟fedT_{k}^{r,\text{fed}}, consists of four components: the computation time Tkr,compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟compT_{k}^{r,\text{comp}} for local model training; uploading time Tkr,uploadsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟uploadT_{k}^{r,\text{upload}}; global aggregation delay; downloading time of the global model. Similar to [40], since the aggregation in the BS is performed extremely fast and the downlink bandwidth is large enough, we assume that the global aggregation delay and downloading time of the global model can be ignored, thus Tkr,fedsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟fedT_{k}^{r,\text{fed}} is defined as

Tkr,fed=Tkr,comp+Tkr,upload.superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟fedsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟uploadT_{k}^{r,\text{fed}}=T_{k}^{r,\text{comp}}+T_{k}^{r,\text{upload}}. (14)

We define Rλrsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝜆𝑟R_{\lambda}^{r} as the estimated minimum convergence round in round r𝑟r to achieve the convergence of global model. We estimate Tkr,fedsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟fedT_{k}^{r,\text{fed}} as the training time of each round before aggregation, thus for round r𝑟r the requirement of the total training time over Rλrsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝜆𝑟R_{\lambda}^{r} is estimated as

Tkr,total=Rλr⋅Tkr,fed,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟total⋅superscriptsubscript𝑅𝜆𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟fedT_{k}^{r,\text{total}}=R_{\lambda}^{r}\cdot T_{k}^{r,\text{fed}}, (15)

Next, the computation time Tkr,compsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟compT_{k}^{r,\text{comp}}, uploading time Tkr,uploadsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟uploadT_{k}^{r,\text{upload}} and minimum convergence round Rλrsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝜆𝑟R_{\lambda}^{r} are formulated, respectively.

V-A1 Computation time

Let c𝑐c denote the number of processing cycles for a particular vehicle to update the local model based on a batch of samples, and fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} denotes the CPU frequency of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k}. Therefore, the computation time of round r𝑟r is given by [52]

Tkr,comp=cfk.superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟comp𝑐subscript𝑓𝑘T_{k}^{r,\text{comp}}=\frac{c}{f_{k}}. (16)

V-A2 Uploading time

The latency for Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} to upload the quantized local gradient of round r𝑟r is

Tkr,upload=ζkrRkr,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟uploadsuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑟T_{k}^{r,\text{upload}}=\frac{\zeta_{k}^{r}}{R_{k}^{r}}, (17)

where ζkrsuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑘𝑟\zeta_{k}^{r} is the number of uploading bits after stochastic quantization and Rkrsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑟R_{k}^{r} is the transmission rate of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} for round r𝑟r.

For quantizing any element gkr,jsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑟𝑗g_{k}^{r,j} in the local gradient 𝐠krsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r} according to Eq. (8), we need to encode ‖𝐠kr‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}\|, sgn​(gkr,j)sgnsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑟𝑗\mathrm{sgn}(g_{k}^{r,j}) and ξj​(𝐠kr,qkr)subscript𝜉𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟\xi_{j}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r},q_{k}^{r}) into bits. Particularly, sgn​(gkr,j)sgnsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑟𝑗\mathrm{sgn}(g_{k}^{r,j}) is encoded by utilizing one bit. Assume that ξj​(𝐠kr,qkr)subscript𝜉𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟\xi_{j}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r},q_{k}^{r}) follows uniform distribution222In practice, ξj​(𝐠kr,qkr)subscript𝜉𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟\xi_{j}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r},q_{k}^{r}) may follow non-uniform distribution. As reported in [15], such non-uniform distribution is a more efficient coding method compared with uniform distribution. However, the non-uniform distribution is much more complicated to analyze and optimize, hence the uniform distribution is considered in this paper and we will consider the non-uniform distribution for future work.. According to [53], it takes at least log2⁡(1+qkr)subscript21superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟\log_{2}(1+q_{k}^{r}) bits to encode each ξj​(𝐠kr,qkr)subscript𝜉𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟\xi_{j}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r},q_{k}^{r}). Moreover, similar to [36], the bits to encode ‖𝐠kr‖normsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}\| is typically negligible for large models. Since 𝐠krsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r} contains d𝑑d elements, according to the above analysis ζkrsuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑘𝑟\zeta_{k}^{r} can be approximated as follows

ζkr=[1+log2⁡(qkr+1)]​d.superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑘𝑟delimited-[]1subscript2superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟1𝑑\zeta_{k}^{r}=[1+\log_{2}(q_{k}^{r}+1)]d. (18)

Next, the transmission rate of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k}, denoted by Rkrsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑟R_{k}^{r}, is formulated. OFDMA is adopted for wireless transmission between the BS and vehicles. The bandwidth is B𝐵B and can be divided into W𝑊W orthogonal subcarriers. Each selected vehicle is assigned with an orthogonal subcarrier. The mobility of each selected vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} has an impact on the transmission rate Rkrsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑟R_{k}^{r}, which depends on the distance dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} between Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} and the BS [54, 55]. According to Shannon’s theorem, the achievable transmission rate of vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} can be represented as

Rkr=BW​log2⁡(1+γkr),superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑟𝐵𝑊subscript21superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟R_{k}^{r}=\frac{B}{W}\log_{2}(1+\gamma_{k}^{r}), (19)
γkr=pk​hkr​(dkr)−ασ2,superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟subscript𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑟superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑟𝛼superscript𝜎2\gamma_{k}^{r}=\frac{p_{k}h_{k}^{r}(d_{k}^{r})^{-\alpha}}{\sigma^{2}}, (20)

where γkrsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑟\gamma_{k}^{r} is the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k}, pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} is the transmit power of vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k}, which remains constant, hkrsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑟h_{k}^{r} and dkrsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑟d_{k}^{r} are the channel gain and distance between vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} and the BS, respectively, where hkrsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑟h_{k}^{r} is calculated according to the normal distribution in [20], α𝛼\alpha is the path loss exponent and σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the noise power, dkrsuperscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑟d_{k}^{r} can be calculated as

dkr=(xkr−xB)2+(yk−yB)2,superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑟superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑟subscript𝑥𝐵2superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝑦𝐵2d_{k}^{r}=\sqrt{(x_{k}^{r}-x_{B})^{2}+(y_{k}-y_{B})^{2}}, (21)

where (xB,yB)subscript𝑥𝐵subscript𝑦𝐵(x_{B},y_{B}) is the coordinate of the BS, and (xkr,yk)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑟subscript𝑦𝑘(x_{k}^{r},y_{k}) is the coordinate of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k}.

V-A3 Minimum convergence round

The minimum convergence round is derived by analyzing the convergence of the quantized federated learning. To facility derivation, we make some assumptions on the local loss function of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} for round r𝑟r, denoted by F​(𝐰kr)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}), as follows:

Assumption 1 (L-Smoothness).

The local loss function F​(𝐰kr)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}) is L𝐿L-smooth for ∀k∈𝒦rfor-all𝑘superscript𝒦𝑟\forall k\in\mathcal{K}^{r} and ∀rfor-all𝑟\forall r, i.e., F​(𝐰k,ir)≤F​(𝐰k,jr)+(𝐰k,ir−𝐰k,jr)T​∇F​(𝐰k,jr)+L2​‖𝐰k,ir−𝐰k,jr‖2𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑖𝑟𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟𝑇∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟𝐿2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟2F(\mathbf{w}_{k,i}^{r})\leq F(\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r})+\left(\mathbf{w}_{k,i}^{r}-\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r}\right)^{T}\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r})+\frac{L}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}_{k,i}^{r}-\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r}\right\|^{2}, ∀𝐰k,irfor-allsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑖𝑟\forall\mathbf{w}_{k,i}^{r} and 𝐰k,jr∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} are the i𝑖i-th and j𝑗j-th local model of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} for round r𝑟r.

Assumption 2 (μ𝜇\mu-Strongly convexity).

The local loss function F​(𝐰kr)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}) is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex for ∀k∈𝒦rfor-all𝑘superscript𝒦𝑟\forall k\in\mathcal{K}^{r} and ∀rfor-all𝑟\forall r, i.e., F​(𝐰k,ir)≥F​(𝐰k,jr)+(𝐰k,ir−𝐰k,jr)+(𝐰k,ir−𝐰k,jr)T​∇F​(𝐰k,jr)+μ2​‖𝐰k,ir−𝐰k,jr‖2𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑖𝑟𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟𝑇∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟𝜇2superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑖𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑗𝑟2F(\mathbf{w}_{k,i}^{r})\geq F(\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r})+\left(\mathbf{w}_{k,i}^{r}-\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r}\right)+\left(\mathbf{w}_{k,i}^{r}-\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r}\right)^{T}\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}_{k,i}^{r}-\mathbf{w}_{k,j}^{r}\right\|^{2}.

Assumption 3 (Boundedness of variance).

The variance of stochastic gradient 𝐠krsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r} of the local loss function F​(𝐰kr)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}) for ∀k∈𝒦rfor-all𝑘superscript𝒦𝑟\forall k\in\mathcal{K}^{r} and ∀rfor-all𝑟\forall r, satisfy that: 𝔼​[‖𝐠kr−∇F​(𝐰kr)‖2]≤δk2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟2superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘2\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r})\|^{2}]\leq\delta_{k}^{2}.

Assumption 4 (Unbiased).

The mean of stochastic gradient 𝐠krsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r} of the local loss function F​(𝐰kr)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}) for ∀k∈𝒦rfor-all𝑘superscript𝒦𝑟\forall k\in\mathcal{K}^{r} and ∀rfor-all𝑟\forall r, satisfy that: 𝔼​[𝐠kr]=∇F​(𝐰kr)𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}]=\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}).

Note that assumptions 1 and 2 on the local loss function can be satisfied by many typical learning models, such as logistic regression, linear regression, and softmax classifiers. Assumptions 3 and 4 are general. Based on Assumptions 1-4, the optimality gap between the average loss function of the global model for a round r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime} after round r𝑟r, denoted by 𝔼​[F​(𝐰gr′)]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔superscript𝑟′\mathbb{E}\left[F(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r^{\prime}})\right] (r′>r)superscript𝑟′𝑟(r^{\prime}>r), and the loss function of optimal global model for round r𝑟r, i.e., F​(𝐰∗r)𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑟F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{r}), is upper bounded by [26]:

𝔼​[F​(𝐰gr′)]−F​(𝐰∗r)𝔼delimited-[]𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔superscript𝑟′𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑟\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[F(\mathbf{w}_{g}^{r^{\prime}})\right]-F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{r}) (22)
≤α​κr′+2​α​κ−1​(L​‖𝐰g0−𝐰∗r‖2+2​Γμ),absent𝛼𝜅superscript𝑟′2𝛼𝜅1𝐿superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔0superscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑟22Γ𝜇\displaystyle\leq\frac{\alpha\kappa}{r^{\prime}+2\alpha\kappa-1}\left(L\left\|\mathbf{w}_{g}^{0}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{r}\right\|^{2}+\frac{2\Gamma}{\mu}\right),

where α=dqkr​K+1𝛼𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟𝐾1\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{q_{k}^{r}K}+1, κ=Lμ𝜅𝐿𝜇\kappa=\frac{L}{\mu}, Γ=2​L​Fδ+1K​∑k=1Kδk2Γ2𝐿subscript𝐹𝛿1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝛿𝑘2\Gamma=2LF_{\delta}+\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\delta_{k}^{2}, here Fδ=F​(𝐰∗r)−1K​∑k=1KFk∗subscript𝐹𝛿𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑟1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘∗F_{\delta}=F(\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{r})-\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}F_{k}^{\ast} with Fk∗=min𝐰kr⁡F​(𝐰kr)superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘∗subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟𝐹superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑟F_{k}^{\ast}=\min\limits_{\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}}F(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{r}), 𝐰g0superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔0\mathbf{w}_{g}^{0} is the initial global model of the training process. By letting the upper bound satisfy the convergence constraint333We note that optimization using upper bound as an approximation has also been adopted in [56] and resource allocation based literature [30][57]., we can obtain

α​κRλr+2​α​κ−1​(L​‖𝐰g0−𝐰∗r‖2+2​Γμ)≤λ.𝛼𝜅superscriptsubscript𝑅𝜆𝑟2𝛼𝜅1𝐿superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔0superscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑟22Γ𝜇𝜆\frac{\alpha\kappa}{R_{\lambda}^{r}+2\alpha\kappa-1}\left(L\left\|\mathbf{w}_{g}^{0}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{r}\right\|^{2}+\frac{2\Gamma}{\mu}\right)\leq\lambda. (23)

Letting the left hand equals to the right hand in Eq. (23), when λ𝜆\lambda is given, we can derive Rλsubscript𝑅𝜆R_{\lambda} based on the fact that the minimum convergence round should be integer, i.e.,

Rλr=⌈(dqkr​K+1)​(L​‖𝐰g0−𝐰∗r‖2+2​Γμλ−2)​κ+1⌉.superscriptsubscript𝑅𝜆𝑟𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟𝐾1𝐿superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑔0superscriptsubscript𝐰∗𝑟22Γ𝜇𝜆2𝜅1R_{\lambda}^{r}=\left\lceil\left(\frac{\sqrt{d}}{q_{k}^{r}K}+1\right)\left(\frac{L{\|\mathbf{w}_{g}^{0}-\mathbf{w}_{\ast}^{r}\|}^{2}+\frac{2\Gamma}{\mu}}{\lambda}-2\right)\kappa+1\right\rceil. (24)

V-B Quantization error

According to [15], the random quantization function 𝒬​(𝐠kr)𝒬superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}) is unbiased, i.e., 𝔼​[𝒬​(𝐠kr)]=𝐠kr𝔼delimited-[]𝒬superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r})]=\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r} for any given 𝐠krsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}. Moreover, assume that d≥(qkr)2𝑑superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟2d\geq({q_{k}^{r}})^{2}, the quantization function is constrained by a upper bound, i.e., 𝔼​[‖𝒬​(𝐠kr)−𝐠kr‖]2≤dqkr​‖𝐠kr‖2𝔼superscriptdelimited-[]norm𝒬superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟superscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟2𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐠𝑘𝑟2\mathbb{E}[\left\|\mathcal{Q}(\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r})-\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}\right\|]^{2}\leq\frac{\sqrt{d}}{q_{k}^{r}}\left\|\mathbf{g}_{k}^{r}\right\|^{2}. Similar with [28], we estimate the upper bound as the quantization error of vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} in round r𝑟r, i.e.,

Ekr=dqkr​‖gkr‖2.superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑟𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptg𝑘𝑟2E_{k}^{r}=\frac{\sqrt{d}}{q_{k}^{r}}\|\textbf{g}_{k}^{r}\|^{2}. (25)

According to Eq. (18) and Eq. (25), we can get the following conclusion, i.e., a higher quantization level would lead to more bit to transmit and a less quantization error Ekrsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑟E_{k}^{r}.

V-C Optimization problem

Our optimization objective is to allocate quantization levels to jointly optimize the estimated training time and quantization error for each vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} in each round r𝑟r, which can be translated into the following problem:

P1:​min qkrP1:superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟min \displaystyle\textbf{P1:}\;\;\;\underset{q_{k}^{r}}{\text{min }}\;\;\; ω1⋅Tkr,total+ω2⋅Ekr,⋅subscript𝜔1superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟total⋅subscript𝜔2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑟\displaystyle\omega_{1}\cdot T_{k}^{r,\text{total}}+\omega_{2}\cdot E_{k}^{r}, (26)
s.t. qkr≥2,a​n​d​qkr∈ℤ+,∀k∈𝒦r,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟2formulae-sequence𝑎𝑛𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑟superscriptℤfor-all𝑘superscript𝒦𝑟\displaystyle q_{k}^{r}\geq 2,and\;q_{k}^{r}\in\mathbb{Z}^{+},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}^{r}, (26a)
1≤K≤N,1𝐾𝑁\displaystyle 1\leq K\leq N, (26b)

where ω1subscript𝜔1\omega_{1} and ω2subscript𝜔2\omega_{2} are the nonnegative weighted factors.

The optimization problem P1 is challenging to solve using conventional methods because it is a non-linear constrained integer optimization problem[58]. Although some techniques, such as the branch and bound method, can provide approximate solutions, their computational complexities are very high[59]. Moreover, the conventional optimization methods are based on the assumption that the channel state information (CSI) is known. However, it is impractical to obtain all CSI information in the real environment[60]. To address these challenges, DRL can be employed to handle imperfect information. By interacting with dynamic channel environments, DRL can train a model by learning from online user behavior and environmental conditions, and thus maximizes the system utility[61, 62]. This makes DRL a promising solution for tackling these problems. Since the centralized DRL framework results in significantly high traffic load, and the high mobility of vehicles makes it difficult for the BS to collect accurate CSI. In the next section, we will propose a distributed DRL scheme to solve the optimization problem P1.

VI Distributed Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Solution

We model the quantization level allocation problem in each round as a distributed DRL process. The duration of each round consists of multiple time steps. For simplicity, we omit the label of round in the DRL process since each round will experience the same training process. In each time step t𝑡t of a round, each selected vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} observes the current local state sk,tsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑡s_{k,t} and takes an action ak,tsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑡a_{k,t} according to the policy π𝜋\pi. Then, the vehicle receives the reward rk,tsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑡r_{k,t} and the environment state changes from sk,tsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑡s_{k,t} to sk,t+1subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡1s_{k,t+1} to start the process in the next time step. Next, the DRL framework including state sk,tsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑡s_{k,t}, action ak,tsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑡a_{k,t} and reward rk,tsubscript𝑟𝑘𝑡r_{k,t} of the vehicle at time step t𝑡t will first be constructed, then the DRL based solution is described.

VI-A DRL framework

VI-A1 State

Each vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} observes its local state to determine the quantization level. In the system model, each vehicle calculates the distance between Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} and BS at time step t𝑡t, i.e., dk,tsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑡d_{k,t}, to determine the position of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} at time step t𝑡t, which reflects the mobility of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k}, thus dk,tsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑡d_{k,t} is set as one local observation at time step t𝑡t. In addition, the BS detects the SNR of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} at time step t𝑡t, i.e., γk,tsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡\gamma_{k,t}, and transmits γk,tsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡\gamma_{k,t} to Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} at the next time step. In this case, Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} receives γk,t−1subscript𝛾𝑘𝑡1\gamma_{k,t-1} at time step t𝑡t, which can reflect the uncertain channel condition at time step t𝑡t, thus γk,t−1subscript𝛾𝑘𝑡1\gamma_{k,t-1} is set as the other local observation at time step t𝑡t. Moreover, according to Eqs. (18), (24) and (25), the optimization objective is affected by the number of bits for the transmission, the minimum convergence round and the quantization error, all the three factors are the functions of the quantization level qk,tsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑡q_{k,t}, thus qk,tsubscript𝑞𝑘𝑡q_{k,t} is set as another local observation at time step t𝑡t. According the above analysis, the state of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} at time step t𝑡t, denoted as sk,t∈𝒮subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡𝒮s_{k,t}\in\mathcal{S}, where 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} is the state space, can be defined as

sk,t=[γk,t−1,dk,t,qk,t].subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡subscript𝛾𝑘𝑡1subscript𝑑𝑘𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡s_{k,t}=[\gamma_{k,t-1},d_{k,t},q_{k,t}]. (27)

VI-A2 Action

Since each vehicle Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} selects its quantization level to improve FL performance, the action of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} at time step t𝑡t is defined as

ak,t=qk,t.subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡a_{k,t}=q_{k,t}. (28)

where qk,t∈𝒜subscript𝑞𝑘𝑡𝒜q_{k,t}\in\mathcal{A} and the space of the quantization level 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is partitioned into 𝒜=[2,…,10]𝒜2…10\mathcal{A}=[2,\dots,10].

VI-A3 Reward function

Since Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} aims to improve FL performance in terms of the training total delay and quantization error, the reward function of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} at time step t𝑡t is defined as

rk,t=−[ω1⋅(Rλ⋅Tkr,f​e​d)+ω2⋅Ekr].subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡delimited-[]⋅subscript𝜔1⋅subscript𝑅𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑟𝑓𝑒𝑑⋅subscript𝜔2superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑟r_{k,t}=-\left[\omega_{1}\cdot(R_{\lambda}\cdot T_{k}^{r,fed})+\omega_{2}\cdot E_{k}^{r}\right]. (29)

The expected long-term discounted reward of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k} is calculated as

G​(πk)≔𝔼πk​[∑t=1Tγt−1​rk,t],≔𝐺subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝔼subscript𝜋𝑘delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript𝛾𝑡1subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡G(\pi_{k})\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\pi_{k}}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{T}\gamma^{t-1}r_{k,t}\right], (30)

where γ∈[0,1]𝛾01\gamma\in[0,1] is the discount factor and T𝑇T is the upper limit of step index. The objective of this paper is to find the optimal policy πk∗superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k}^{*} to maximize the expected long-term discounted reward of Vksubscript𝑉𝑘V_{k}.

VI-B Solution

In this section, we first describe the training stage to obtain the optimal policy, then introduce the testing stage to test the performance under the optimal policy.

VI-B1 Training stage

Since the state and action space are discrete and the DDQN algorithm is suitable to solve the DRL problem under the discrete state and action space. Moreover, DDQN can easily find the optimal action when the state-action space 𝒮×𝒜𝒮𝒜\mathcal{S}\times\mathcal{A} is large. Therefore, we utilize the DDQN algorithm to obtain the optimal policy in the training stage.

The DDQN framework includes the target network and the double Q-learning method as an extension of DQN [63]. It uses a deep neural network (DNN) to approximate the Q-function that maps state-action pairs (sk,ak)subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘(s_{k},a_{k}) to the Q-values Q​(sk,ak)𝑄subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘Q(s_{k},a_{k}). The Q-function can be approximated by using the weight parameter θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}.

A DNN model consists of an input layer, a hidden layer, and an output layer, where each layer is fully connected to the next layer. The input of the DNN is the state vector sk,tsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑡s_{k,t} and the output is the Q-value corresponding to each action. The output layer consists of linear units, and the intermediate hidden layer is activated by rectified Linear units (ReLUs) f​(x)=max​(0,x)𝑓𝑥max0𝑥f(x)=\text{max}(0,x).

DDQN decouples the target network θk′superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘′\theta_{k}^{{}^{\prime}} as well as the prediction network θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} to reduce the correlation between the prediction value and target value. The prediction value Q​(sk,t,ak,t;θk)𝑄subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘Q(s_{k,t},a_{k,t};\theta_{k}) is obtained from the prediction network θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} and the target value yk,tsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑡y_{k,t} is obtained from the target network θk′superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘′\theta_{k}^{{}^{\prime}}.

Here, the prediction network Q​(sk,ak;θk)𝑄subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘Q(s_{k},a_{k};\theta_{k}) is used for action selection and the target network Q​(sk,ak;θk′)𝑄subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘′Q(s_{k},a_{k};\theta_{k}^{{}^{\prime}}) is used for value evaluation. The pseudocode of the DDQN training process is described in Algorithm 2.

Firstly, the prediction Q-network θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} and the target Q-network θk′superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘′\theta_{k}^{{}^{\prime}} are initialized, where the prediction network θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} is randomly initialized and the target network is initialized as the prediction network θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k}. A replay buffer ℬℬ\mathcal{B} with enough space is constructed to cache the transitions at each time step (lines 1-3).

Then, the algorithm will iteratively train the prediction Q-network and target Q-network in different episodes. In the first episode, the location of Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} is reset to where it enters the coverage area of the BS, i.e., dk,0subscript𝑑𝑘0d_{k,0} is set to −RBsubscript𝑅𝐵-R_{B}. Then quantization level qk,0subscript𝑞𝑘0q_{k,0} and channel gain hk,0subscriptℎ𝑘0h_{k,0} are randomly initialized. As we can calculate the initial SNR according to Eq. (20), Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛V_{n} can observe the state at time step 00, i.e., sk,0=[γk,0,dk,0,qk,0]subscript𝑠𝑘0subscript𝛾𝑘0subscript𝑑𝑘0subscript𝑞𝑘0s_{k,0}=[\gamma_{k,0},d_{k,0},q_{k,0}] (Lines 4-6).

Afterwards, in one time step, based on a probability threshold ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, an action is randomly selected from the action space 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} for exploration. Otherwise, the RL training process selects the greedy action. Mathematically, it can be expressed as (lines 7-11).

ak,t={a​r​g​maxak​Q​(sk,t,ak),1−ϵ,Randomly choose from​𝒜,ϵ.subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡cases𝑎𝑟𝑔subscript𝑎𝑘max𝑄subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡subscript𝑎𝑘1italic-ϵmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionRandomly choose from𝒜italic-ϵmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressionmissing-subexpressiona_{k,t}=\left\{{\begin{array}[]{*{20}{c}}arg\;\underset{a_{k}}{\text{max}}Q(s_{k,t},a_{k}),&{1-\epsilon},\\ {\text{Randomly choose from}}\;\mathcal{A},&{\epsilon}.\end{array}}\right. (31)

Then, according to the action ak,tsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑡a_{k,t}, the agent can observe the environment and calculate the next state sk,t+1subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡1s_{k,t+1} and reward rk,t+1subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡1r_{k,t+1} to get the experience. The experience (sk,t,ak,t,rk,t+1,sk,t+1)subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡1subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡1(s_{k,t},a_{k,t},r_{k,t+1},s_{k,t+1}) is then stored in the replay buffer (lines 12-13).

When the number of the stored tuples is larger than I𝐼I, the parameters of prediction network and target networks, i.e., θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} and θk′superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘′\theta_{k}^{{}^{\prime}}, are updated literately.

The iteration in time step t𝑡t (t=1,2,…,TI𝑡12…subscript𝑇𝐼t=1,2,...,T_{I}) to update θksubscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k} and θk′superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘′\theta_{k}^{{}^{\prime}} is described as follows when the number of the stored tuples is larger than I𝐼I. each vehicle first uniformly samples I𝐼I tuples from replay buffer to form a mini-batch. Then each vehicle inputs each tuple into the target network and prediction network. Each vehicle first inputs sk,tsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑡s_{k,t} and ak,tsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑡a_{k,t} into the prediction network and outputs the prediction value Q​(sk,t,ak,t;θk)𝑄subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘Q(s_{k,t},a_{k,t};\theta_{k}), then each vehicle inputs sk,t+1subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡1s_{k,t+1} and rk,t+1subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡1r_{k,t+1} into the target network and calculates the target value as

yk,t=rk,t+1+γ​Q​(sk,t+1,a​r​g​maxak​Q​(sk,t+1,ak;θk);θk′).subscript𝑦𝑘𝑡subscript𝑟𝑘𝑡1𝛾𝑄subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡1𝑎𝑟𝑔subscript𝑎𝑘max𝑄subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡1subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝜃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘′y_{k,t}=r_{k,t+1}+\gamma Q(s_{k,t+1},arg\;\underset{a_{k}}{\text{max}}Q(s_{k,t+1},a_{k};\theta_{k});\theta_{k}^{{}^{\prime}}). (32)

Then the loss function can be calculated as

L​(θk)=𝔼​[(yk,t−Q​(sk,t,ak,t;θk))2],𝐿subscript𝜃𝑘𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑡𝑄subscript𝑠𝑘𝑡subscript𝑎𝑘𝑡subscript𝜃𝑘2L(\theta_{k})=\mathbb{E}\left[(y_{k,t}-Q(s_{k,t},a_{k,t};\theta_{k}))^{2}\right], (33)

and the prediction network updates its parameters using ∇L​(θk)∇𝐿subscript𝜃𝑘\nabla L(\theta_{k}) to minimize the loss function through gradient descending (lines 14-18).

The target network is updated every C𝐶C time steps (lines 19-20). The flow diagram of the DDQN algorithm is shown in Fig. 2.

VI-B2 Testing stage

To evaluate the performance of the proposed algorithm, we employ the optimal neural network parameters obtained in the training stage and start to test its performance. The pseudocode of the testing stage is shown in Algorithm 3.

VI-C Complexity Analysis

In this subsection, we analyze the complexity of the DDQN algorithm. The complexity of DDQN algorithm is affected by the number of step intervals. For each step interval, the prediction network computes the gradients and updates the parameters, while the target network updates the parameters without calculating the gradients. Since the network structure of the prediction network is the same as that of the target network, the complexity of updating the parameters of the target network is the same as that of the prediction network. Let G𝐺G be the computational complexity of the prediction network to compute the gradient, and U𝑈U be the computational complexity of the prediction network to update the parameters. Therefore, the complexity of DDQN algorithm in one time step is O​(G+2​U)𝑂𝐺2𝑈O(G+2U). Moreover, the training processes is not activated until the replay experience buffer is larger than the min-batch, Note that the above algorithm loops over T𝑇T episodes, each of which includes TIsubscript𝑇𝐼T_{I} step steps. Therefore, the complexity of the DDQN algorithm is calculated as O​((T⋅TI−I)​(G+2​U))𝑂⋅𝑇subscript𝑇𝐼𝐼𝐺2𝑈O((T\cdot T_{I}-I)(G+2U)).

VII Simulation Results

In this section, the optimal weight factors between the total training time and QE are figured out through simulation comparisons. On the basis of the optimal weight factors, we conduct simulations to verify the effectiveness of the proposed DDQN-based quantization level allocation algorithm in the training phase and testing phase. All simulations are based on hardware environment (Intel Core i7 CPU) and software environment (Python 3.8.6). We consider the VEC network proposed in Section III, including a BS and several vehicles. Each participating vehicle is treated as an agent and participates in the DDQN-based quantization level allocation algorithm. Excluding ω1subscript𝜔1\omega_{1} and ω2subscript𝜔2\omega_{2}, the simulation parameters are shown in Table II.

VII-A Training Stage

In Fig. 3, taking the weight setting of ω1=ω2=0.5subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔20.5\omega_{1}=\omega_{2}=0.5 as representative, we investigate the relationship between the average reward per training episode and the number of training iterations to investigate the convergence behavior of the proposed method, which is referred to as DQN-based gradient quantization method (DQN-GradQ) in the simulations for simplicity. It can be seen that the training reward gradually stabilizes as the number of episodes increases, which verifies the good convergence performance of our algorithm.

VII-B Optimal weight factors

The condition ω1+ω2=1subscript𝜔1subscript𝜔21\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}=1 is set for convenience, allowing the value of ω2subscript𝜔2\omega_{2} to change in response to changes in ω1subscript𝜔1\omega_{1}. Fig. 3 shows the performance of FL in terms of training loss, test accuracy, average total training time, average quantization error, and long-term discounted reward for different values of ω1subscript𝜔1\omega_{1}.

As shown in Fig. 4-(a), when ω1=0.1subscript𝜔10.1\omega_{1}=0.1 and ω1=0.3subscript𝜔10.3\omega_{1}=0.3, the train loss value decreases more slowly at the beginning of the training. This is because the vehicles are farther from the base station initially, resulting in poor channel conditions and larger transmission delays. However, the vehicles tend to select higher quantization levels under these weight settings to reduce quantization error. As the channel conditions improve later on, the impact of quantization error becomes significant, and focusing relatively more on quantization error can lead to a lower train loss value.

ω1=0.7subscript𝜔10.7\omega_{1}=0.7 and ω1=0.9subscript𝜔10.9\omega_{1}=0.9 mean that more attention is given to transmission delay of the vehicles. The training loss decreases rapidly at the early stage of the training due to the large transmission delays. However, due to the relatively less focus on quantization error, lower quantization levels are chosen more often, leading to a higher converged training loss value. When ω1=0.5subscript𝜔10.5\omega_{1}=0.5, equal weight is given to the total training time and quantization error, which helps ensure that the system maintains the quality of model convergence while reducing transmission overhead, resulting in the fastest convergence speed compared to other ω1subscript𝜔1\omega_{1} values. Similarly, as shown in Fig. 4-(b), the model trained with ω1=0.5subscript𝜔10.5\omega_{1}=0.5 outperforms all other schemes in test accuracy.

Fig. 4-(c) and (d) indicate that ω1=0.1subscript𝜔10.1\omega_{1}=0.1 and ω1=0.3subscript𝜔10.3\omega_{1}=0.3 place more emphasis on quantization error, resulting in smaller quantization error and more frequent selection of higher quantization levels during training, allowing for convergence with fewer communication rounds. Conversely, when ω1=0.7subscript𝜔10.7\omega_{1}=0.7 and ω1=0.9subscript𝜔10.9\omega_{1}=0.9, the vehicles tend to choose lower quantization level number, resulting in larger quantization error and an increase in the total training rounds needed for convergence, further leading to an increase in the total training time. The setting of ω1=0.5subscript𝜔10.5\omega_{1}=0.5 does not favor either objective, and under this weight configuration, the system can maintain a low quantization error while achieving faster convergence.

Fig. 4-(e) compares the long-term discounted reward of the scheme for different values of ω1subscript𝜔1\omega_{1}. The setting of ω1=0.5subscript𝜔10.5\omega_{1}=0.5 effectively balances the total training time and quantization error, representing a robust learning strategy that maintains stable performance across different environments and avoids extreme scenarios, accumulating more rewards in the long term.

In summary, ω1=0.5subscript𝜔10.5\omega_{1}=0.5 is identified as the optimal choice. In federated learning, rapid convergence and high accuracy are two key objectives. The setting of ω1=0.5subscript𝜔10.5\omega_{1}=0.5 encourages the system to find the best balance between reducing communication rounds and controlling quantization error, allowing the system to achieve faster convergence without sacrificing too much accuracy. Moreover, this robust weight setting provides good environmental adaptability. In the dynamically changing environment of VEC, the system needs to adapt to different communication conditions and vehicle mobility. The setting of ω1=0.5subscript𝜔10.5\omega_{1}=0.5 offers sufficient flexibility, enabling the system to adjust its quantization strategy according to the current environmental state, thus maintaining good performance under various circumstances. Hence, we set ω1=0.5subscript𝜔10.5\omega_{1}=0.5 for the following experiments.

VII-C Testing Stage

We compare "DQN-GradQ" with several state of the art gradient quantization baselines, including the adaptive quantization method [64], which is referred to as "Ada-GradQ" in the simulations, and the fixed quantization method. For the fixed-bit quantization method, the number of quantization bits is 2, 6, and 10 are referred to as "Fix(2 bits)", "Fix(6 bits)", and "Fix(10 bits)" in the simulations, respectively.

Fig. 5-(a) and (b) show the training loss and test accuracy of FL under five different quantization schemes, respectively. Fig. 5-(a) shows the training loss comparison for different schemes. We can see that "DQN-GradQ" outperforms all baseline schemes in FL convergence rate. This is because in the early stage of the training, the vehicles are driving far away from the BS, thus the channel conditions are not good owing to the large distances between the vehicles and BS, which incurs the large transmission delay. As the vehicles driving towards the BS, the channel conditions are improve, thus transmission delay of the vehicles are reduced. In this case, the vehicles can gradually increase the quantization level thus reducing the quantization error and converging to the target loss value with less communication rounds. Moreover, we can see that the "Ada-GradQ" approach can get less the number of communication rounds in the early stage of training, but the training loss value is higher than that of "DQN-GradQ". This is because the predefined heuristic algorithm in "Ada-GradQ" cannot make good decisions in the later training phase to guarantee the accuracy of the gradient. In addition, we can see that the training loss of "Fix (2-bit)" decreases very quickly in the early stage, but it converges to a high value. This is because its lower quantization level will produce a larger quantization error. On the other hand, the training curves for "Fix (6bit)" and "Fix (10bit)" steadily decrease throughout the training rounds, however, they need more rounds to converge. This is because they use more bits to quantize the gradient during training and waste a lot of transmission overhead during training, which slows down the convergence speed. Fig. 5-(b) shows the test accuracy of FL of different schemes. It can be seen that the accuracy of "DQN-GradQ" is higher than that of all baseline schemes under the same training rounds, indicating the lower loss leads to higher performances. Hence, the experimental results show the effectiveness of gradient quantization using DDQN.

Fig. 6 shows the average total training time, average quantization error, and long-term discounted reward of the FL training process under different schemes when the number of the participating vehicle is 8. Fig. 6-(a) shows that our scheme "DQN-GradQ" has the lowest average total training time compared to all the baseline schemes. This is because, the proposed scheme can adaptively adjust the quantization level according to the channel conditions, reduce the number of rounds required for convergence, and then reduce the total training time. Fig. 6-(b) shows that the average quantization error of our scheme is lower than that of "Ada-GradQ" and "Fix (6-bit)" and higher than that of "Fix (10-bit)". This is because the proposed scheme can increase the quantization level and reduce the quantization error according to the improvement of channel conditions. However, Fig. 5-(a) shows that "Fix (10-bit)" cannot converge to a lower loss. Therefore, our scheme can minimize the average total training time of FL while ensuring the convergence of FL compared to all baseline schemes. Fig. 6-(c) compares the long-term discount rewards under different gradient quantization schemes. As can be seen, the long-term discount bonus of "DQN-GradQ" is always higher than that of other schemes. This is because "DQN-GradQ" can adaptively adjust quantization level allocation according to environmental changes to maximize long-term discount rewards.

Fig. 7 shows the total training time, quantization error, and long-term discount reward for the four schemes with different numbers of selected vehicles, respectively. It can be seen from Fig. 7-(a) that the total FL training time of the four schemes gradually decreases with the increase of the number of participating vehicles. Our scheme "DQN-GradQ" is with the considerable lower FL total training time, because more participating vehicles lead to less rounds for convergence, and our scheme dynamically adjusts the allocation of quantization levels according to the change of the environment, hence, the number of communication rounds required for FL convergence is further reduced. It can be seen from Fig. 7-(b) that for the four schemes, the quantization error of different numbers of participating vehicles remains stationary, and our scheme has a relatively low quantization error. This is because the magnitude of the quantization error depends only on the size of the assigned quantization level. That is, the larger the quantization level, the smaller the quantization error, and vice versa. As shown in Fig. 7-(c), with the increase of the number of participating vehicles, the long-term discount rewards of the four schemes gradually increase, and our scheme DQN-GradQ has the largest long-term discount reward. This is because when the number of participating vehicles is larger, the rounds required for convergence is smaller, and the total training time is smaller. The proposed scheme can reasonably allocate the quantization level according to the change of channel conditions to further reduce the training time, which reflects the effectiveness of our scheme in minimizing the training time of FL.

VIII Conclusions

In this paper, we investigated the optimization of the training time and quantization error of FL with gradient quantization in VEC. First, we proposed a mobility and model-aware vehicle selection rule to select vehicles at the beginning of each round. After determining the participating vehicles, we considered the uncertainty of channel conditions caused by vehicle mobility in VEC, and proposed a distributed quantization level allocation scheme based on DDQN to jointly optimize the training time and quantization error of FL. Simulation results demonstrated that the proposed DDQN-based gradient quantization scheme outperforms all benchmark schemes in terms of FL training time, and can minimize the training time while ensuring the FL convergence.
